abstract: John Edwards is opening a new law practice. | The Justice Department is set to announce the final details of a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase. | Dropbox is seeking $250 million in financing. | Timothy F. Geithner’s new job presents less of a conflict than many critics claim.
snippet: John Edwards is opening a new law practice. | The Justice Department is set to announce the final details of a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase. | Dropbox is seeking $250 million in financing. | Timothy F. Geithner’s new job presents les...
lead_paragraph: “Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer,” Peter Lattman and Kim Severson write in DealBook. “Now, Mr. Edwards is returning to his roots and opening a new law practice. The plaintiffs’ firm, Edwards Kirby, reunites him with his former partner, David F. Kirby, and includes on its payroll his eldest daughter, Cate Edwards.”

abstract: The case against JPMorgan may set a precedent for cases against other major banks and industries like health care, where fines have been growing.
snippet: The case against JPMorgan may set a precedent for cases against other major banks and industries like health care, where fines have been growing.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:44 p.m. | When Tony West arrived in a Justice Department conference room to put the finishing touches on a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, he saw a familiar number flash on his cellphone.

headline.main: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line
headline.print_headline: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

abstract: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.
